thread.title: Newcastle Central constituency General Election 2017 - parties, candidates and history of the seat

author: Simon Meechan
title: Newcastle Central constituency General Election 2017 - parties, candidates and history of the seat
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
If you’re due to cast your vote in the Newcastle Central constituency on June 8 we’ve got everything you need to know right here. 
Britain will go to the polls to elect a government and prime minister after Theresa May called a snap general election. 
We’ll be covering events on our live blog on election day, but in the meantime we’ve got the information you need before you decide which box to put your cross in. What constituency am I? 
Enter your postcode below to find out more details on your constituency. Which parties and candidates standing in Newcastle Central? Labour - Chi Onwurah Chi Onwurah (Photo: Sunday Sun) 
Labour’s MP in Newcastle Central since 2010, Chi Onwurah was born in Wallsend and raised in Kenton. 
She studied electrical engineering at Imperial College, London. After graduating she launched a career in IT, in both hardware and software development. Before becoming an MP, Ms Onwurah was head of telecoms technology for Ofcom. 
Ms Onwurah says she has consistently championed Newcastle and its people, while standing up for public services and job investment. Conservative - Steve Kyte Steve Kyte 
Originally form South Wales, Mr Kyte left school at 16 to join the RAF, where he was posted to RAF Boulmer in Northumberland. After leaving the air force, he worked at Newcastle Airport, before later joining Northumbria Police as a civilian staff member, 
The married father of two volunteers as a school governor and as a counsellor for a victim support charity. He also volunteers for Friends of Gosforth Central Park. 
Mr Kyte, who holds masters’ degrees from Newcastle and Northumbria Universities, says he would work with the Theresa May to deliver a “good deal for Britain” in the Brexit negotiations. Liberal Democrats - Nick Cott Nick Cott 
The Lib Dem candidate is a sitting councillor who represents West Gosforth. Mr Cott works for the Open University, as an associate lecturer and teaches history. 
He also has experience teaching at both Newcastle and Sunderland universities, and tutors at Joseph Cowan Lifelong Learning in Newcastle. 
Mr Cott, who also stood in Newcastle Central in 2010, says his party’s aim is to fight the Conservative’s approach to Brexit and says Newcastle deserves a “better choice” than Labour or the Tories. Green Party - Peter Thomson Peter Thomson (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Once Lord Mayor of Newcastle, Peter Thomson is a former Labour councillor who has represented Elswick on Newcastle City Council for 20 years. 
He switched to the Green Party three years ago. 
He says only the Green Party understand the “devastating effects” of climate change, pollution and human rights abuses. 
Mr Thomson says his party’s focus on renewable energy, Universal Basic Income, housing, transport and waste makes the Green the “only” viable choice. UKIP - David Muat 
David Maat is the UK Independence Party Candidate for Newcastle. 
ChronicleLive has contacted the local UKIP branch to ask for information about him. What was the result in Newcastle Central in 2015? 
Chi Onwurah took 19,301 votes - a 55% share. 
The Conservatives came second, with 19% of the vote. UKIP, in third, took a 15% share. The Lib Dems won 6% of the vote and the Green Party got 5%. Read More
